title: Feeling stuck? Here's how to know when it's time to leave your job | Ada Chen Rekhi
key_insights: Use 'Curiosity Loops' - ask 5-10 people specific, unbiased questions to get contextual advice instead of relying on one person's opinion
Apply the 'explore and exploit' framework in early career - explore different roles/industries to learn, then exploit what works
Define personal values through structured exercises to make better decisions aligned with your authentic self rather than external expectations
Don't be the 'boiling frog' - regularly assess if your current situation is trending positively or negatively for your growth and learning
Most people don't need a coach - exhaust alternatives like mentors, courses, and communities first before investing in coaching
Practice 'eating your vegetables' - force yourself to do difficult but important things 10-12 times before deciding you don't like them
Use the five-minute rule for productivity - commit to just five minutes on your most important daily task to overcome procrastination
Working with a romantic partner requires clear domains of responsibility and the ability to engage in constructive conflict without taking feedback personally

guest_background.current_role: Executive coach and co-founder of Notejoy

topics_discussed: Curiosity loops methodology for gathering advice

memorable_quotes: It's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there.
Don't be the frog. If you take a frog and you put in a pot and you increase the temperature degree by degree by degree, the frog doesn't notice and before it knows, it's boiled alive.
We're not powerless, even though this game is rigged. We can study the game, we can help each other, and we can actually start to call out some of those rules and then find ways around them.
recommended_for: early career professionals seeking strategic guidance
mid-career individuals feeling stuck or unfulfilled
women in tech and leadership roles
summary: Ada Chen Rekhi shares practical frameworks for making better career decisions, including her 'Curiosity Loops' method for gathering contextual advice and strategies for building an authentic, values-driven career path. The conversation covers everything from early career optimization to executive coaching, with particularly valuable insights for women navigating leadership roles in tech.
